But then the wife shouted at the thieves
and she told her husband as follows:
"Why do you fool, for the sake of one cake, when you see a thief, not call out?"
The husband clapped his hands and he laughed and said:
"Ah, you stupid slut!
I shall now certainly have the cake.
I will not give it to you under any circumstances."
When the people of this world hear about this, without exception they laugh out aloud.
The ordinary people are also like this.
For the sake of trifling success in this world they fraudulently make a show of calm and silence.
They are invaded by fake worries and the villain constituted by all sorts of evil,
and they lose the good dharma of Buddhism.
They fall into the sāntú hell
and still do not get frightened.
They seek the Way to leave this mundane world,
but they still have their place in the Five Desires.
They are morbidly attached to fooling around
and even when they encounter great bitterness
they do not consider this as any disaster.
Just like those stupid people, and there is no difference.
Once upon a time there was a man
who was angry with someone else.
He was all upset, and not glad at all.
Someone asked him as follows:
"Why are you in such a morose mood these days?"
Then the man answered him as follows:
"There is someone who has slandered me
and my strength is not great enough to retaliate.
I do not know by what method I can retaliate against him.
That is the only reason why I am in this morose mood."
There was someone who spoke to him as follows:
"Only the Bitoluo curse can harm that calumniator.
But there is one disastrous point:
before you have harmed him him you will have harmed yourself."
When the man had heard this he was very pleased:
"I just wish you could teach me this curse.
Even if I will have to harm myself, I do, in the end, hope to harm him."
The people of this world are also like this.
Because of their anger they wish to seek the curse
in order to cause worries for the other party.
But in the end they do not harm him.
First they act on their anger, and then they cause worries and harm to themselves.
They fall into the (three hells:) hell, life as a beast, and life as a hungry ghost.
It is just like that fool, all the same and no different!
Once upon a time there was a man
who arrived from northern India in southern India.
When he had settled for a long time he married a woman of the place and they became man and wife.
At one time the wife was preparing a repast for her husband.
When the husband got the food he gulped it down quickly
and he did not avoid the heat (and burnt himself).
The wife then was surprised at this
and she told her husband as follows:
"There are no thieves her, or people who will take this away from you,
what is the hurry?
Why are you in such a haste
and do not enjoy the meal slowly?"
The husband replied to the wife:
"There is a pleasant secret
which I cannot tell you."
When the wife heard his words
she thought he was very odd.
Several times she asked him,
and after a fair amount of time he answered:
"From my ancestor's time onwards,
the rule was always to eat fast.
I now imitate this practice.
That is why I am so fast, that's all!"
The ordinary people of this world are also like this.
The do not get to the correct truths
and they do not properly understand the good and the bad,
but they make up these wicked forms of demeanour,
and do not consider this a shame
but say:
"From my ancestors onwards we have acted according to this law.
to the end of my days I will accept this law and practice it,
and to the end I shall not abandon it.
They are like this fool who practises his fast eating and considers it a good rule to follow.
Once upon a time there was a dignitary.
He sent someone with some money to someone else's garden
to buy some anpoluo-fruits,
and he wanted to eat these.
So he gave him orders as follows:
"Those that look good, are sweet and tasty, these you must buy."
Then the man took the money and went to buy the fruit.
The owner of the fruit said:
"All these fruits growing on the trees are tasty and they look good
there is not one that is bad.
You try one fruit!"
The man who was buying the fruit said:
"I should now taste every one of these,
only after that should I make my choice.
If I only taste one
how can I understand the situation?"
Immediately he took the fruit
and he tasted every single one.
He took them along and returned home.
When the dignitary saw him
he disliked these and and did not eat of them,
and so they were all lost.
The people of this world are also like this.
They hear that by keeping to prohibitions and to generosity one will gain great wealth and joy,
that one's body will always be comfortable and that one will not suffer disasters.
But they are not willing to put their faith in this,
and they make this speech (expressing their thought and addressing themselves):
"As for getting good fortune through generosity,
only when I have experienced this happening to myself can I believe in this.
With their own eyes they see that in the present world honour, low status, and poverty all are rewards for antecedent karmic action,
but they are intellectually unable to generalise from one example in order to find the rule of karma.
and it is then that they will not believe in the Buddhist truths.
They absolutely must experience things themselves
but one fine morning their life comes to an end
and their property is lost.
It is like that tasting of fruit,
and they lost them all.
Once upon a time there was a man
who had taken two wives.
If he approached one, he got angry looks from the other
and he could not decide between the two.
So right between the two wives he lay straight on his back and slept.
It happend that there was a rainstorm
and his house leaked
and water as well as dirt seeped down together
and happened to fall right into his eye.
But since there was this agreement from before
he did not dare to get up and get out of the way of the dirt.
So in the end he lost the sight in both his eyes.
The ordinary people in this world are also like this.
Their close associates and their cronies
routinely engage in actions against the Buddhist law.
They produce for themselves a kind of karma of confusion
and they fall into the ways of the Three Evils.
Forever they dwell in the realm of the cycle of life and death
and they lose the eye of wisdom.
They are like that fool:
for the sake of his two wives he lost both his eyes.
Once upon a time there was a man
who arrived at his wife's home.
He noticed they were pounding rice,
and he headed for the place where they were doing this.
He stole some rice corns and put them into his mouth.
When the wife came and saw her husband
she wanted to talk with him,
but his mouth was full of this rice
and he never made any answer.
Because he was ashamed before his wife
he could not get himself to get rid of the rice in his mouth.
The wife was surprised but did not say anything.
With her hand she probed him to see what was the matter.
She thought that he had a swelling in his mouth
and she spoke to her father as follows:
"My husband has just arrived,
and all of a sudden he has got this swelling in the mouth
so he cannot speak at all.
Her father summoned a doctor to treat him.
At that time the doctor declared the following:
"This disease is extremely serious,
only if we use the surgical knife to solve the problem
we can manage to cure the disease.
Then he cut open his mouth with a knife
and the rice came out from inside
so that the matter came into the open.
The people of this world are also like this.
They commit evil deeds
and they offend against the prohibitions of purity,
and then they go on to hide their mistakes
and are unwilling to disclose them.
They fall into hell, as hungry ghosts of animals.
Like this fool
who because of a petty shame was not willing to spit out the rice
and had his mouth cut open with a knife,
so that (in the end) he brought out into the open his mistake.
Once upon a time there was a man
who was riding a black horse
and entered the ranks of a military formation that was attacking a band of robbers.
Because he was terrified he was unable to join the battle
so he smeared himself with blood and with sweat on the face
and fraudulent he gave the appearance of being dead.
He lay down among the dead.
The horse he was riding was discarded by him.
When the army had disbanded
he wanted to returned home
so he cut off the tail of someone else's white horse to bring along.
When he had arrived in his own home
there was someone who asked him as follows:
"The horse you were riding,
where is it now?
Why are you not riding it?"
He answered as follows:
"My horse has died,
so I have taken the ail along."
A bystander spoke as follows:
"Your horse was originally black.
How come that the tail is black?"
The man remained silent and gave no answer.
He was laughed at by the others.
The people of this world are also like this.
They speak of themselves as good and beautiful,
and of their comportment as characterised by a loving attitude.
They do not consume wine or meat.
But on the other hand they kill living creatures
and the add to the severe sufferings of life.
Arbitrarily they call themselves good
and their is no wickedness that they do not bring about.
They are like that fool
who fraudulently says that his horse has died.
Once upon a time there was a king
and he made arrangements for the preaching of the Buddhist dharma:
"All brahmans, as long they are in my state, I establish the system that they must wash themselves clean.
Those who do not wash themselves clean I shall chase away and order to be whipped, and I shall impose on them all manner of exhausting labour.
There was a brahman who was holding an empty washing basin
and he fraudulently claimed that he had washed himself clean.
Someone else put some water in the cheater's basin
and the cheater poured it out.
He made the following speech:
"If I have not washed,
then let the king himself wash me."
Because of the king's intentions, he was thus able to avoid the labour imposed by the king.
He wildly claimed that he had washed himself clean,
but in fact he had not washed himself.
The vulgar people who become monks are also like this.
They shave their heads and they dye their clothes.
but in their personal behaviour, in fact, they reduce to nothing the prohibitions.
They fraudulently make a show of maintaining the prohibitions
but they thereby hope to material benefits and moreover to avoid the forced labour imposed by the king.
Looked at from outside they resemble monks
but inwardly, in fact, they are empty fraudulent.
They are like someone carrying along an empty bottle
and they only have the external appearance (lacking the inner reality).
Once upon a time there was a man
who had put some grain in a jar.
A camel stuck its head into the jar and ate the grain
but could not get its head out again.
Since the camel-owner could not get it out, he considered this a worrying state of affairs.
There was an old man who came upon the scene and told the camel-owner as follows:
"Don't you worry!
I shall teach you to get it out.
If you follow my words
you are bound to get it out quickly.
You must cut off its head,
then you can get it out quickly."
So the camel-owner followed these words
and using a knife it cut off its head.
So on the one hand he killed the camel, and on the other he ruined the jar.
Silly people like this are laughed at by the people of this world.
The ordinary fools are also like this.
They are hopeful in their minds for Buddhist knowledge
and their aspiration is to seek the Three Vehicles of Buddhism.
They should keep the prohibitions
and to guard against the wicked features of this world.
But because of the Five Desires they ruin the pure prohibitions.
Once they have offended against the prohibitions and have distanced themselves from the Three Vehicles,
They give free rein to their minds and to their thoughts, and there are no misdeeds they do not commit.
The Vehicles and the Pure Prohibitions all get rejected,
It is like the case of that fool, where both the camel and the jug were lost.
Once upon a time there was a peasant
who was travelling in a city
and saw a daughter of a king.
Her face was all regular
as it is rarely found in this world.
Day and night he thought of her,
and his emotions were unable to stop.
He was longing to sleep with her
but he had no way to achieve his aim.
His face turned all yellow
and then he developed a serious disease.
All the people who were in contact with him, when they saw him they would ask why this person was in that state.
And he would reply to his neighbours, saying:
"Some time ago I saw the king's daughter.
Her face was very regular.
I longed to sleep with her
but because I could not achieve my end, therefore I got ill. That's all.
If I do not get to sleep with her,
then I am bound to die, that's for sure.
His friends spoke to him as follows:
"We shall create positive conditions for you,
and we shall bring it about that you achieve your aims
Don't be upset!"
When he met them some days later
they spoke to him as follows:
"We have taken action on your behalf so that you can have your way.????
But the princess did not want to sleep with you."
When the peasant heard this
he laughed with delight,
and he imagined he would get to sleep with her.
The fools of this world are also like this.
They make no distinction between the seasons spring, autumn, winter and summer.
In the middle of winter they cast seed in the earth
and they hope to reap fruits.
Pointlessly they waste their effort
and they go empty and reap no harvest.
The sprouts and the stems, the twigs and the leaves, all these are lost.
they imagine that this is sufficient
and they imagine that the Buddhist knowledge can already be complete,
and then they imagine that Buddhist knowledge can already be ascertained.
They are like that peasant with his hopes for the king's daughter.
Once upon a time people from a border state was unfamiliar with donkeys.
They heard others explain: donkey's milk is very tasty,
and they had not the faintest idea of all this.
At the time the people had got hold of a male donkey
and they wanted to get milk from it it.
They quarrelled and together they held down the beast:
there were those among them who held the head,
there were those who held the ears,
there were those who held the tail,
there were those who held the feet,
and there were those who held the sexual organ.
Every one desired to get it first,
and to drink the milk first.
When they had got hold of the donkey's sexual organ
they imagined it was the breast
and they squeezed it,
hoping to get milk from it.
All these peope got bored with this
and they got no result whatsoever:
they only wore themselves out
and wasted their time and got nothing.
They were laughed at by all the people of their time.
The vulgar dissenters are also like this.
They hear others make explanations about the Way of the Buddha
but where they should not seek things,
they arbitrarily produce ambitions
they give rise to all sorts of wicked points of view
they go naked and cultivate hunger techniques,
they throw themselves from cliffs and walk through fire,
and because of these wicked points of view they fall into the evil ways.
They are like those fools who misguidedly seek milk.
Once upon a time there was a man
who spoke to his son during the night as follows:
"Tomorrow I shall to to that village with you.
There is something I must get there."
The son, having heard this speech,
when it was early in the next morning,
he did not in fact ask his father
but all on his own he went to that place.
When he had got to that place
his body was exhausted,
and he got nothing there,
moreover he got nothing to eat.
He was so hungry and thirsty, he was about to die.
But he quickly turned round
and sought to see his father.
When the father saw that his son had come
he thoroughly berated his son as follows:
"You are immensely stupid,
and you have no wisdom!
Why didn't you wait for me.
Now you have gone and returned to no good purpose.
In vain you have suffered these adversities.
The man was laughted at by all the people in the world.
Vulgar people are also like that.
If they manage to become monks
they shave off their beards
and they wear the monk's clothes of the Three Dharmas.
They do not seek any enlightened master,
but they ask to receive the dharma of the Way of the Buddha.
They lose their meditation peace,
their qualifications in the Way of the Buddha, their meritorious virtue, the wonderful fruits of the monk, these they all lose.
They are like that fool
who for no good purpose went to that place and then back
and who wore himself out for nothing.
In form they are like monks
but in fact they have achieved nothing.
Once upon a time there was a king
who wanted to enter the Garden of No Worries
and to enjoy himself there, to indulge in delights.
He ordered one minister as follows:
"You pick up a table
and take it to that Garden.
I want to sit by it and take my rest."
Now this subordinate was ashamed and was unwilling to take the table
and he told the king as follows:
"I cannot simply carry it with my hands,
I hope to carry it on a pole."
Thereupon the king placed 36 tables on his back (on a shoulder pole),
and he urged him to carry these to the Garden.
A fool like this will be laughed at by the world.
The ordinary people are also like this.
When they see one hair of a woman on the ground
they they they keep to the prohibitions
and they are unwilling to pick it up.
Afterwards, when they are confused by worries
then all the 36 kinds of things, hair on the head, body hair, nails, teeth, excrement, urine and impure things of this sort, they will not regard as impure,
the 36 kinds of things they will pick up all at the same time
and in so doing will not feel shame.
To the end of their days they will not discontinue their practice.
They are like that fool, who got to shoulder the tables.
Once upon a time there was a man
who suffered a disease in the lower parts.
The doctor said:
"You should pour in medicine from the behind, then it can be cured."
Then he assembled the instrument to inject the liquid
and wanted, accordingly, to inject the liquid from behind.
But before the doctor had arrived,
the took the medicine and ate it.
His stomach got all swollen and he was about to die
and could not control himself.
When the doctor arrived,
he wondered why this was going on,
and so he asked him:
"Why are you in this state?"
The ordinary people are also like this.
They want to study and cultivate chán meditation,
and they survey all sorts of methods.
When they are supposed to contemplate the impurity of the world
they, on the contrary, contemplate the frequent breathing technique;
When they should have been contemplating the frequent breathing technique
they, on the contrary contemplate the Six Realms of Existence.
They turn things upside down
and they do not have anything that is stably basic to them.
To no purpose they lose their lives.
They get themselves into dire trouble
but they do not consult a competent master.
Once upon a time there was a father and a son
who were travelling along with friends.
The son went into a forest
and was bitten by a bear:
the bear's claws mauled his body.
In desperate panic he got himself out of the forest
and returned to the company of his friends.
When the father saw that he son's body had been badly injured,
he was surprise and asked him as follows:
"How you now come to suffer these injuries?"
The son replied to his father as follows:
"There is a kind of creature
whose body has stubby hair,
and it came at me to destroy me."
The father took a bow and arrow
and went to the forest.
There he saw an immortal
whose hair was very long,
and he was about to shoot him.
A bystander spoke to him as follows:
"Why are you shooting him.
This person is of no harm.
You should correct those who have committed mistakes.
The stupid people of this world are also like this.
they get sworn at and humiliated by those who although they wear Buddhist garb do not in fact practice the Way of Buddhism,
and they wantonly harm good and virtuous people.
These are likened to that father
who, just because a bear harmed his son, unjustly turned on an immortal.
Once upon a time there was a country bumpkin.
When he came to a rural community
he saw good sprouts of grain,
and it was growing in abundance.
He asked the man in charge of the grain as follows:
"How are you able to cause this grain to get into such beautiful shape?
The owner answered as follows:
"I evenly tend to the field
and everywhere I add dung and urine
therefore the grain gets to be like this."
This country bumpkin then followed these words,
and he used dung and urine
to get his fields into proper shape.
When putting the seed into the earth
he was afraid that if he stamped on the earth with his own feet the earth would get compressed and the wheat would not grow:
I must sit on a bed
and make other people carry me along in a kind of palanquin,
and from above I shall spread the seed,
and in that way things will be fine.
Then he ordered four men
each person to lift one leg of the bed,
and when he got to the field he spread the seed.
The soil got even more compressed
and he was laughed at by the others.
He was afraid of the damage done by his two legs
and added (the damage of) eight more legs.
Ordinary people are also like this.
When they cultivate the field of the keeping of prohibitions
so that the good sprouts will grow,
then they ought have someone as their teacher and ask his advice,
they should receive proper instruction
and make the sprouts of the Buddhist dharma grow.
But they, on the contrary, go against these rules.
They commit many kinds of evil acts.
Thus they bring it about that the sprouts of the prohibitions do not grow.
They are like that man
who was afraid of the effect of his own two legs,
but imposed the addition of eight (other) legs.
Once upon a time there was a monkey
who was beaten by a grown-up man
against whom he was no match.
So, on the contrary, he turned his resentment on the grown-up man's little boy.
Ordinary fools are also like this.
Those whom they originally hate
they keep replacing forever with new ones.
They have already ceased to exist and are matters of the past.
but the fools regard the latter-born phenomena as the former.
And thus they wildly create anger in themselves,
and their poisonous anger becomes forever stronger.
Just like those silly monkeys
who have been beaten by an adult, but who, on the contrary, are angry at his small child.
In ancient times King Āxiūluó saw that the sun and moon were shining so brightly,
he blocked them off with his hands.
An ignorant ordinary person maltreated an innocent dog (thinking it had eaten the moon to produce an apparent eclipse).
The ordinary people are also like this.
In their greed and in their anger they are completely stupid
and they needlessly inflict suffering on their bodies.
They lie down to sleep on spikes and thorns,
with the five hot objects they roast their bodies.
This is like the case of the eclipse of the moon
where one unjustly beats the dog.
Once upon a time there was a woman
and she suffered severely from a pain in the eye.
Someone familiar with the woman asked her as follows:
"Your eyes are hurting?"
She replied as follows:
"They are hurting."
That woman then went on to say:
"If one has eyes they are bound to hurt.
Although mine have not yet started to hurt
I wish I could rip them out,
because I am afraid that they will hurt later."
A bystander said:
"As long as the eye is there, it will either hurt or not;
but if it is not there one will forever suffer pain."
In principle, stupid people are also like this.
They learn that wealth and honor are the basis of decline.
They are afraid (of wealth etc) and did not show generosity,
and they fear retribution for this failure.
When they get richer in property
they suffer heavily from bitter troubles.
Someone has spoken as follows:
"If you show generosity you will either suffer distress or joy.
If you show no generosity you will suffer poverty and misery (in future lives)."
It is like that woman
who cannot bear the pain at hand
and then wants to remove the eye.
And that way she makes the pain worse.
Once upon a time there was a father and a son
and for some business they were travelling together.
Suddenly, roadside robbers came upon the scene,
and they wanted to fleece him.
His son had those golden pendants on his ear.
When the father saw that the thieves suddenly emerged
he was afraid his son would lose the ear rings
so he pulled at them with his hands.
The ear would not come off at the time,
so for the sake of the jade ear pendant he then cut off his son's head.
Within no time the thieves then went on to leave father and son alone.
So the father placed his son's head back on the child's head,
but it could not be put in place properly.
A fool like this is laughed at by the people of this world.
Ordinary people are also like this.
For the sake of material benefit they create specious theories.
They maintain the propositions there is no rebirth, there is rebirth
there is no time interstice between lives, there is a time interstice between lives,
there is no effective technique of the mind, there is an effective technique of the mind,
there are no wild imaginings of all sorts, there are wild imaginings of all sorts.
Other people, using this kind of discourse about the dharmas, refute what they discuss,
and they say:
"In our theories there is no such claim."
In this way the fool will speak wildly for the sake of material profit,
and he will lose the the fruits of the way of the monks.
His body will be destroyed, and his life will come to an end.
He will fall into the three wicked ways.
Like that fool
who, for the sake of a small material benefit cut off his son's head.
Once upon a time there was a band of robbers
who together went about their robbery and thievery.
They took a great deal of property,
and then they divided the booty among themselves.
They decided on equal division and divided the booty accordingly.
The only thing was there was a Buddhist garment from Lùyě the colour of which was not right.
They considered this an inferior part of the spoils
and they gave it to the person of the lowest status.
The one who got the worst part got angry
and he felt he had suffered a great unfair loss.
He went to the city and offered his booty for sale.
And so the well-to-do senior people offered him high prices.
The money he alone got hold of was twice the amount of his fellow thieves.
And then he was delighted, and jumped up and down in limitless joy.
This is like the people of this world
who do not know whether generosity does or does not get rewarded,
and who practice petty generosity so as to get reborn in Heaven and so as to obtain infinite joy.
And then they will again regret this,
and they regret that they were not generous on a large scale.
With generosity it is also like this:
One puts in little effort and gets large results.
Once upon a time there was a monkey
who was holding a handful of beans in his fist.
By mistake he lost one bean on the ground
and he threw away the beans in his hand
wanting to find the one that he had lost.
Before he had even got hold of one bean
the ones he had thrown away before the chickens and ducks had eaten up completely.
When ordinary people become monks they are also like this.
to begin with they break one prohibition
they are unable to repent on this.
Because they do not repent
they go ever more wildly astray.
And thus they spill everything.
They are like that monkey
who having lost one of his beans
throws them all away.
Once upon a time there was a man
who was walking along in the street.
and on his way he found a golden weasel.
He was beside himself with joy,
took hold of it and put it into into his breast pocket.
Crossing the road he walked on.
When he came to a river, he wanted to cross,
he took off his outer garment and put it on the ground.
When he looked for it, the golden weasel had turned into a poisonous snake.
This man reflected deeply:
"One should rather be bitten to death by this poisonous snake...
One needs to put it into his breast pocket again
and then since his mind is mysteriously moved to an extreme extent
the poisonous snake will be transformed again into gold."
But when the foolish bystanders saw that the poisonous snake turned into a real treasure
they considered that the change was ordinary,
and when he picked up the poisonous snake
and put it inside his breast pocket
he was bitten to death by the poisonous snake.
Thus he lost his body and his life.
The fools of this world are also like this.
They see what is goot but they go for material gain,
inside they have no genuine heart.
Only for material profit do they come and attach themselves to the Buddhist truth
but after their lives are finished they fall into the evil place (hell).
It is like picking up the poisonous snake
and then to be bitten by it and to die.
Once upon a time there was a poor man
who was walking along in the street
and on his way, by chance, he picked up a sack of gold coins.
He was extraordinarily delighted in his heart
and he then proceeded to counting the cash.
Before he had counted all of it
the owner of the money suddenly arrived on the scene
and he took all the money back.
The man, at that point, regretted that he had not quickly left the scene.
His feelings of regret were bitter in the extreme.
Those who meet the dharma of the Buddha are also like this.
Although they encounter the meritorious realities of the Three Treasures
they do not diligently work on the expedient means and cultivate the good karma.
Then suddenly their life is finished
and they fall into the three wicked ways.
Like that fool
who left the scene having the money taken away by the owner. (empty 而 for rhythm?)
Just as the gātha says.
Today they plan this task,
the next day they plan that task.
To the delights they get attached, and they do not contemplate the bitterness.
Before they know it the "villain of death" arrives.
They keep busy attending to all sorts of duties.
Ordinary people are all like this.
They are like this man counting his cash,
in fact they are also like this.

div.head: （九一）貧兒 Once upon a time there was a poor man

p.seg: Once upon a time there was a poor man
who was in possession of a trifling property.
When he saw a hugely rich man
he wished he could be equal with this rich man,
but because he could not become his equal
even though he had only a small quantity of goods, he wanted to throw them away into the river.
A bystander spoke to him as follows:
"Although these are few things, they still can prolong your life by several days.
Why are you throwing them away
and throw them into the river?
The fools of this world are also like this.
Even when they become monks,
when to the slightest degree they get material advantage
they have hope in their minds
and they always harbour feelings of dissatisfaction.
They cannot be put on a par with men of high virtue,
but they gain their material advantage.
When they see a senior person, a person of superior virtue,
someone who has learnt a great deal and who has received many gifts as signs of respect,
then they desire to equal him,
and because they cannot equal him,
they harbour worries and bitterness in their hearts.
Then they wish they could cease in their effort to achieve the Buddhist Way.
Just like that fool
who wanted to equal the rich man
and threw away his own property in the process.
Once upon a time there was a wet nurse
who was walking along the road with a child in her arms.
She was tired from walking
and she fell asleep, and she would not wake up.
At the time there was a man
who had a happiness pill which he gave to the little child.
When the child had got hold of the pill, he grew very fond of the nice taste
and showed no concern for his body or his property:
this person then divested himself of his tongues, locks, necklaces and garments
and took them all away.
The monks are also like this.
Their joy is in the trifling various duties.
In the realm of confusion they are greedy for unimportant benefits.
By the "villain" of cares and worries, they get taken away from them their merit and virtue and he "jade" of the treasure of Buddhist prohibitions.
They are like the small child.
Because he craved the unimportant flavour,
everything he had the "villain" took away from him.
Once upon a time there was an old lady
who was taking a nap under a tree.
A bear wanted to come and catch her.
At that time the old mother made a circle around a tree and ran away.
The bear immediately took up the pursuit.
With one arm it embraced the tree
and was about to catch the old lady
The old lady could not but panic.
At that time, with the tree between them???? she squeezed the against it with her two hands.
The bear was unable to move.
There was someone else who came to this place.
The old lady spoke to him as follows:
"If you catch him together with me, we can share the meat."
At that time that man believed what the woman said
and immediately they gained control of the bear.
Once they had gained control of the animal
the old lady immediately left the bear where it was and ran away.
The man (who had helped her) got into great trouble with the bear.
A fool like that will be laughed at by the world.
Ordinary people are also like this.
They produce all sorts of different theories,
and although these are neither good nor beautiful
the style is elaborate and heavy,
and it has all sorts of flaws,
and they do not achieve their aims.
Then they abandon the things and in the end they are lost.
Later, other people get hold of this,
and they desire to provide proper explanations for it.
But they do not properly understnad the ideas,
and on the contrary they are troubled by them.
They are like this fool.
Once upon a time there was a man
who was sleeping with another man's wife.
Before they had finished their intercourse,
the husband came home from elsewhere
and there and then he found out what was happening.
He stayed outside the main gate
waiting for the moment when the adulterer came out
and wanted to kill him.
The wife spoke to her lover as follows:
"My husband has already found out what is happening,
and there is no way of getting out.
Only with the moni-pearl can you manage to get out.
The barbarians call the drain "moni",
and she wanted the man to escape through the drain.
The man misunderstood this
and thought this was about a moni pearl.
Everywhere he sought,
but he did not know where it was.
Then he made this speech:
"I do not see any moni pearl.
If I do not see the Moni pearl
And in no time, the man was killed by the returning husband.
Ordinary people are also like this.
Someone says to them
in the cycle of life and death
there is no constancy,
there is bitterness and emptiness
and there is no real "I".
If one leaves these two realms of discontinuity and of continuity
and finds one's place in the Middle Way of Buddhism,
if one passes through this Middle Way
then it is possible to attain liberation.
The ordinary man misunderstands this.
and he seeks in the world for the bounded and the non-bounded, and the having an "I" and the lacking an "I" in the living creatures,
but to the very end they never get to contemplate the principle of Way of the Mean.
Suddenly their life is finished
They are killed by the inconstancy of things (於 for the sake of rhythm only, ungrammatical!)
They are submersed into the three evil ways.
They are like that fool
who suffered harm from the other one.
Once upon a time there were two pidgeons, one male and one female,
and they shared one nest.
When the autumn fruits were ripe, they picked the fruits and filled their next.
At a later time the fruits had dried and they had become less in volume,
and they filled only half the nest.
The male was angry at the female and said:
"Picking the fruit is a hard business that requires dedication.
Now you have eaten half of the fruit
and only one half of them is left!"
The female pidgeon replied as follows:
"I did not eat the fruit by myself.
The fruit has diminished in volume by itself!"
The male pidgeon believed none of this.
He grew angry and said:
"If you did not eat the fruit by yourself
then how come the fruit has become so much less?"
And with his beak he hacked away at the other pidgeon and killed her.
After a few days had passed
the skies sent down great rain
the fruit got soaked wet
and they became as they had been before.
When the male pidgeon saw this
then the generated remorse:
"That mate of mine did indeed not eat the fruit.
I have killed her for no good reason."
Singing mournfully he called upon the female pidgeon:
"Where have you gone?"
The ordinary people are also like this:
There is pervasion in their breasts,
they irresponsibly choose their desire for pleasure,
and they fail to contemplate the impermanent nature of this.
They offend against the serious prohibitions
and they regret having done that afterwards.
What do they achieve in the end?
Afterwards all they have are sadness and sighs.
Just like that stupid pidgeon.
Once upon a time there was a master artisan
who was in the service of the king.
He could not bear the hardship involved
and he claimed untruthfully that his eyes had gone blind.
In this way he escaped form the hardship.
There was another master artisan who heard about this
and he wanted to destroy his own eyes
and in that way escape from hardship and hard labour.
Someone spoke to him as follows:
"Why are you mutilating yourself?
Just go ahead and put up with the hardship!"
A fool like this will be laughed at by the world.
The ordinary people are also like this.
For petty fame and material benefit they go ahead and speak wrongly
and they destroy the pure prohibitions.
Their bodies die, and their fate is ended.
They are engulfed in the Three Wicked Ways.
They are like this fool
who, for a trifling material benefit,
ruined his own eye.

div.head:
（九七）為惡賊所劫失㲲喻
昔有二人為伴 Once upon a time there were two men who were companions

p.seg: Once upon a time there were two men who were companions
and together they travelled in the open countryside.
One of the two was wearing a felt jacket,
and this was stolen by thieves on the way.
The other man ran away
and fled into the undergrowth.
The man who had lost the piece of felt had wrapped a piece of gold cash into the top of the piece
and he spoke to the thieves as follows:
"This garment is worth one piece of gold cash.
I want to buy it back for one piece of gold cash.
The thief said:
"All right: where's the money?"
And then the man untied the bundle, took the money, showed it to the man.
and spoke to the thief as follows:
"This is real gold.
If you do not trust my words,
in the undergrowth here there is a goldsmith,
and one can go and consult him."
When the thief saw this
he went on to take that man's jacket too.
In this way the fool lost both the filt jacket and the cash.
he lost his own material benefit
and in addition he brought it about that the other (his travel companion) lost his.
Ordinary people are also like this.
The cultivate the qualities of the Buddhist way
and they create their meritorious acts
which is then taken away from them by that thief: their worries.
They lose their good dharmas
and they lose their meritorious acts.
Not only do they lose their own material benefits
they also caus others to lose their karma.
Their bodies are ruined, and their life is ended.
Theya re engulfed in the Three Wicked Ways.
Like that fool,
both they and this fool, they lose what they have.
Once upon a time there was a little child
who was playing on land (by the sea)
and who caught a large turtle.
He wanted to kill the animal
but he did not know the expedient means how to go about it
and he asked someone else as follows:
"How can I get to kill the animal?"
Someone spoke to him as follows:
"If you just throw it into the water
then it can be killed."
Then the little boy, because he believed in these words, threw the turtle into the water,
and when the turtle had got into the water,
it immediately swam off.
Ordinary people are also like this.
They wish to protect their six organs
and they wish to cultivate their merit.
They do not understand the expedient means
and they ask others as follows:
"By what convenient means can I get liberated?"
The dissenters, the devils and the murderous divinities, and his bad friends tell him:
"As long as you pay the utmost attention to the Six Kind of Dust, the excessive passions, and your Five Desires,
and if you do as we are telling you,
you are sure to be liberated.
Such fools do not think true thoughts
but they use the right words.
Their bodies will be ruined and their life will come to an end.
They will be engulfed in the Three Wicked Ways.
They resemble the little boy who throws the turtle into the water.
Into this sutra produced by me,
I have mixed into humorous talk.
In many places it contravenes the correct preachings of Buddhism;
one must see if the meaning does or does not corresponding to the truth.
The case is like that of a bitter powerful medicine
which one mixes in with sugar cane honey.
The medicine is for putting a violent end to disease.
This sutra is also like that.
Within the true teaching of the dharma there is joking
and it is like alcoholic drinks.
The true dharma is full of Buddhist tranquility,
and it shines bright over the human world.
This is like taking a medicine designed to make one vomit
in order to cleanse the inside of one's body.
And when I now, in accordance with this meaning,
broadcast forth the message of keeping one's Buddhist tranquility,
it is like the Ajiatuo medicine:
one puts leaves wraps it up in them.
Once you have taken the medicine and you have applied the strong substance,
then as for the leaves, one goes on to throw them away.
The humour is like the leaf-wrapping,
and the true significance is inside it.
The wise will pick the correct meaning
and the humour he should reject.
The Garland of Folly produced by the honoured Saṅgasena ends here.
